name: Assam
description: Assam, the gateway to Northeast India, is known for its tea gardens, rich biodiversity, and the mighty Brahmaputra River. Home to the one-horned rhinoceros and vibrant cultural traditions.
history: Assam has a rich history dating back to the ancient Kamarupa Kingdom. It was ruled by the Ahom dynasty for nearly 600 years before becoming part of British India. The state has been a melting pot of various cultures and ethnicities.

festivals.name: Bihu
festivals.summary: The most important festival of Assam celebrated three times a year

festivals.name: Ambubachi Mela
festivals.summary: Annual Hindu mela at Kamakhya Temple

name: Arunachal Pradesh
description: The 'Land of the Dawn-Lit Mountains', Arunachal Pradesh is India's easternmost state with pristine natural beauty, diverse tribal cultures, and Buddhist monasteries.
history: Arunachal Pradesh has been inhabited by indigenous tribes for millennia. It was known as the North-East Frontier Agency (NEFA) during British rule and became a full-fledged state in 1987.

festivals.name: Ziro Music Festival
festivals.summary: Annual outdoor music festival in Ziro Valley

name: Meghalaya
description: The 'Abode of Clouds', Meghalaya is famous for its living root bridges, stunning waterfalls, caves, and being one of the wettest places on Earth.
history: Meghalaya was carved out of Assam in 1972. The state is home to the Khasi, Jaintia, and Garo tribes, each with distinct cultural traditions and matrilineal societies.

festivals.name: Nongkrem Dance
festivals.summary: Harvest festival of the Khasi tribe

festivals.name: Wangala
festivals.summary: Harvest festival of the Garo tribe

name: Manipur
description: The 'Jewel of India', Manipur is known for its natural beauty, rich culture, classical dance form Manipuri, and the floating Loktak Lake.
history: Manipur has a recorded history of over 2000 years. The Meithei kingdom was independent until the British colonial period. It became a state of India in 1972.

festivals.name: Yaoshang
festivals.summary: Manipuri version of Holi celebrated for five days

name: Mizoram
description: The 'Land of the Hill People', Mizoram is known for its dramatic hills, pleasant climate, and the unique bamboo flowering phenomenon that occurs once every 48 years.
history: Mizoram was historically inhabited by various Mizo tribes. It was annexed by the British in 1890s and became a Union Territory in 1972, gaining statehood in 1987.

festivals.name: Chapchar Kut
festivals.summary: Spring festival celebrating the clearing of jhum fields

name: Nagaland
description: The 'Land of Festivals', Nagaland is home to diverse tribal cultures, each with unique traditions, colorful attires, and the famous Hornbill Festival.
history: Nagaland has been inhabited by Naga tribes for centuries. After a period of conflict, it became the 16th state of India in 1963, with special provisions under Article 371A.

festivals.name: Hornbill Festival
festivals.summary: Festival of Festivals showcasing Naga culture every December

festivals.name: Moatsu
festivals.summary: Festival of the Ao tribe celebrated in May

name: Sikkim
description: A Himalayan wonderland, Sikkim is known for its biodiversity, Buddhist monasteries, adventure tourism, and stunning views of Kanchenjunga, the third-highest peak in the world.
history: Sikkim was an independent Buddhist kingdom until 1975 when it became India's 22nd state. It has a unique cultural blend of Lepchas, Bhutias, and Nepalese communities.

festivals.name: Losar
festivals.summary: Tibetan New Year celebrated with traditional rituals

bestTime: March to June, September to December

name: Tripura
description: The 'Land of Two Goddesses', Tripura is known for its palaces, temples, rich cultural heritage, and being home to diverse tribal communities.
history: Tripura was ruled by the Manikya dynasty for over 1300 years before merging with India in 1949. It has a rich history of art, culture, and architecture influenced by Bengali and tribal traditions.

festivals.name: Kharchi Puja
festivals.summary: Festival of 14 deities celebrated in July
